emerging_technologies.name: Decentralized AI Governance (DAIG)
emerging_technologies.description: A system where AI decision-making processes are governed by a decentralized network of stakeholders, ensuring transparency and reducing bias.
emerging_technologies.societal_implications: Could lead to more democratic AI development, but raises concerns about decision paralysis and governance complexity.
emerging_technologies.adoption_factors: Widespread adoption depends on regulatory support, technological maturity of blockchain, and public trust in decentralized systems.

emerging_technologies.name: Neural Identity Markets
emerging_technologies.description: Markets where individuals can trade or lease their neural data or cognitive enhancements, secured by blockchain technology.
emerging_technologies.societal_implications: Raises privacy concerns, potential for exploitation, but also offers new economic opportunities for individuals.
emerging_technologies.adoption_factors: Adoption depends on legal frameworks for neural data rights, public perception, and advancements in neural interface technology.

emerging_technologies.name: Tokenized Space Resources
emerging_technologies.description: Tokenization of extraterrestrial resources allowing for fractional ownership and investment in space mining operations.
emerging_technologies.societal_implications: Could revolutionize space economy, but poses legal and ethical challenges regarding ownership and exploitation of space resources.
emerging_technologies.adoption_factors: Requires international space law agreements, technological breakthroughs in mining and tokenization, and investor interest.

emerging_technologies.name: Zero-Knowledge Smart Grids
emerging_technologies.description: Energy grids that use zero-knowledge proofs to ensure privacy and security in energy transactions and management.
emerging_technologies.societal_implications: Enhances energy security, reduces potential for cyber attacks, but requires significant investment in both blockchain and energy infrastructure.
emerging_technologies.adoption_factors: Adoption hinges on energy sector's move towards decentralization, regulatory approval, and advancements in zero-knowledge technology.

mainstream_technologies.name: AI-Driven Smart Contracts
mainstream_technologies.description: Smart contracts that adapt and execute based on real-time AI analysis of external data, enhancing contract flexibility and efficiency.
mainstream_technologies.adoption_status: Increasingly integrated into legal, financial, and real estate sectors due to efficiency and reduced need for intermediaries.

mainstream_technologies.name: Blockchain-Verified Autonomous Decisions
mainstream_technologies.description: Autonomous systems making decisions that are verified and logged on a blockchain for transparency and auditability.
mainstream_technologies.adoption_status: Widespread in logistics, supply chain management, and autonomous driving sectors where transparency and accountability are crucial.

epoch_themes.description: A shift towards decentralized decision-making processes across various sectors using blockchain technology.
epoch_themes.societal_impact: Promotes transparency and reduces centralized control, potentially leading to more equitable systems but also challenging traditional governance structures.
epoch_themes.global_trends: Driven by the need for trustless systems in a globalized world, with increasing regulatory interest in blockchain technologies.

epoch_themes.description: The trend of converting physical and digital assets into blockchain-based tokens for fractional ownership and trading.
epoch_themes.societal_impact: Enables new economic models but introduces complexity in asset management, legal frameworks, and taxation.
epoch_themes.global_trends: Growing as a means to democratize investment in high-value assets, influenced by the rise of DeFi and asset-backed tokens.
